abstractContent.text: We describe a 'How was your day?'
(HWYD) Companion whose purpose is to establish a comforting and supportive relationship with a user via a conversation on a variety of work-related topics.

The system has several fairly novel features aimed at increasing the naturalness of the interaction: a rapid 'short loop' response primed by the results of acoustic emotion analysis , and an 'interruption manager', enabling the user to interrupt lengthy or apparently inappropriate system responses, prompting a replanning of behaviour on the part of the system.
The 'long loop' also takes into account the emotional state of the user, but using more conventional dialogue management and planning techniques.
We describe the architecture and components of the implemented prototype HWYD system.

introductionContent.text: As the existence of this workshop shows, there is a good deal of interest in a type of spoken language dialogue system distinct from the traditional taskbased models used for booking airline tickets and the like.

The purpose of these 'social agent' systems is to be found in the relationship they can establish with human users, rather than on the assistance the agent can provide in giving information or solving a problem.
Designing such agents provides many significant technical challenges, requiring progress in the integration of linguistic communication and non-verbal behaviour for affective dialogue ().
In this paper, we present the implementation of a Companion Embodied Conversational Agent (ECA) which integrates emotion and sentiment detection with more traditional dialogue components.
